    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Meeting high priority deadlines related to compliance with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act
of 2002 and other key projects.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Participants in the 2005 Incentive Plan included AirNet&#146;s executive officers, Joel E. Biggerstaff,
Gary W. Qualmann, Larry M. Glasscock, Jr., Jeffery B. Harris, Wynn D. Peterson, Ray L. Druseikis
and Craig A. Leach, and certain department managers and department directors. At the start of the
2005 fiscal year, there were 45 participants in the 2005 Incentive Plan. As of the end of the 2005
fiscal year, there were 43 participants in the 2005 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">53
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Payments under the 2005 Incentive Plan were based on a combination of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income (as
determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan) for the 2005 fiscal year, operating
performance of AirNet&#146;s various business components and the achievement of personal goals assigned
to each participant. The Compensation Committee approved personal goals for executive officers and
reviewed the personal goals for other participants. The personal goals approved by the
Compensation Committee for each of the executive officers related to specific business objectives
related to general business operations (e.g., regulatory compliance, expense reductions, etc.) and
each business component (e.g., execution of specific contracts with customers and vendors, cost
reductions, service improvements, etc.). No incentive compensation was to be paid to the executive
officers under the 2005 Incentive Plan for the achievement of personal goals unless AirNet attained
the designated threshold level of pre-tax income (other than certain amounts payable to Wynn D.
Peterson, as discussed below).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">No incentive compensation was to be paid under the 2005 Incentive Plan unless AirNet achieved a
designated threshold level of pre-tax income (as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive
Plan) for the 2005 fiscal year. If the designated threshold level were achieved, incentive
compensation payments would increase at predetermined pre-tax income levels until the maximum
compensation payout of $1.9&nbsp;million was reached at approximately 200% of pre-tax income for the
2004 fiscal year, determined without regard to the 2004 fiscal year impairment charges related to
property and equipment and goodwill.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Once the overall amount of incentive compensation was determined based upon AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income
(as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan), incentive compensation was allocated to
Bank, Express, Jetride and corporate based upon pre-established targets. Incentive compensation
was then allocated to the participants most closely involved in managing each of those business
areas based upon each participant&#146;s base salary. Finally, participants must have achieved their
pre-established personal goals to achieve their maximum incentive compensation payment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The maximum percentage of annual base salary that the following executive officers could have
received as incentive compensation under the 2005 Incentive Plan was: (i)&nbsp;for Joel E. Biggerstaff,
100%; (ii)&nbsp;for Gary W. Qualmann, Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. and Jeffery B. Harris, 75%; and (iii)&nbsp;for
Ray L. Druseikis and Craig A. Leach, 50%. In connection with his promotion in June&nbsp;2005 to Senior
Vice President, Jetride Services, the incentive compensation which Mr.&nbsp;Peterson could have received
under the 2005 Incentive Plan was modified to include two components. He was eligible to receive
incentive compensation up to a maximum amount of $75,000 (50% of his $150,000 annual base salary
prior to the increase) based on the level of achievement through June&nbsp;30, 2005 of his personal
goals in the position as Vice President, Strategic Planning and Analysis, and achievement by AirNet
of a designated level of pre-tax income (as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan),
for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005. The amount of $60,000 in incentive compensation was paid
to Mr.&nbsp;Peterson in respect of the six-month period ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, which payment was made in
March of 2006. Mr.&nbsp;Peterson was also eligible to receive incentive compensation from zero to a
maximum amount of $161,250 (75% of his $215,000 annual base salary after the increase) based on the
level of achievement of personal goals related to the performance of Jetride for the period from
July 1 through December&nbsp;31, 2005, and achievement by Jetride, and AirNet, of designated levels of
pre-tax income (as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan) for the six months ending
December&nbsp;31, 2005. In March of 2006, the amount of $46,438 in incentive compensation was paid to
Mr.&nbsp;Peterson in respect of the six-month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Except for payments to the executive officers, payments under the 2005 Incentive Plan were paid in
quarterly payments commencing with the second quarter of the 2005 fiscal year based upon AirNet&#146;s
year-to-date financial performance. Except as described above in respect of Mr.&nbsp;Peterson, payments
of incentive compensation to AirNet&#146;s executive officers serving at the time of such payments, were
made in March of 2006 based upon AirNet&#146;s performance for the 2005 fiscal
year. New employees who qualified for the 2005 Incentive Plan were eligible to participate on the
first day of the calendar quarter following their date of hire.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On August&nbsp;9, 2005, the Board, upon the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, had adopted
the following amendments and clarifications to the 2005 Incentive Plan to address the possibility
that a transaction for the sale of AirNet would be consummated prior to the end of the 2005 fiscal
year. In such event, (i)&nbsp;participants in the 2005 Incentive Plan would have been entitled to
receive incentive compensation measured as a percentage of their full year base salary rather than
a pro-rated portion; (ii)&nbsp;to the extent that bonuses were based in part on pre-tax income (as
determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan) for the 2005 fiscal year, such pre-tax
income would have been measured through the month ending immediately prior to the consummation date
of the sale transaction; (iii)&nbsp;to the extent bonuses for any individual were determined in part
based upon the performance of a business unit against a pre-determined target, the performance of
such business unit would have been based upon the performance through the month ending immediately
prior to the consummation date of the sale transaction versus the targeted performance through such
month end; and (iv)&nbsp;individuals who were employed by AirNet at the time of the consummation of a
sale transaction would have been entitled to a bonus under the 2005 Incentive Plan whether or not
they were employed at the time the bonus was to be paid.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On November&nbsp;20, 2005, the Board, upon the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, ratified a
change to the 2005 Incentive Plan to provide that, for purposes of computing the pre-tax income of
AirNet for the 2005 fiscal year for purposes of the 2005 Incentive Plan, the $16.1&nbsp;million non-cash
impairment charge recorded by AirNet in the third quarter of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">54
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">the 2005 fiscal year would be
disregarded and the pre-tax income for the 2005 fiscal year would be computed as if no impairment
charge had been incurred.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the 2005 fiscal year and the fiscal quarter ending March&nbsp;31, 2006, AirNet made payments
under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan in the aggregate amount of approximately $1.6&nbsp;million.
In March of 2006, the executive officers of AirNet were paid the following amounts under the 2005
Incentive Plan: Joel E. Biggerstaff &#151; $250,000; Jeffery B. Harris &#151; $190,250; Gary W. Qualmann -
$148,000; Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. &#151; $141,125; Wynn D. Peterson &#151; $106,438 ($60,000 in respect of
the six-month period ended June&nbsp;30, 2005; $46,438 in respect of the six-month period ended December
31, 2005); Craig A. Leach &#151; $72,000; and Ray L. Druseikis &#151; $29,000 (became a participant effective
July&nbsp;1, 2005 following his election as an executive officer of AirNet and employment with AirNet
effective June&nbsp;30, 2005.)
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">After reviewing AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income (as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan),
the operating performance of AirNet&#146;s various business components, the level of achievement of the
personal goals assigned to each executive officer and, in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Peterson, Jetride&#146;s
pre-tax income (as determined under the terms of the 2005 Incentive Plan), at the meeting of the
Compensation Committee held on March&nbsp;8, 2006, the Compensation Committee determined the amount of
incentive compensation to be paid to each executive officer (other than Mr.&nbsp;Peterson) in respect of
the 2005 fiscal year and the incentive compensation to be paid to Mr.&nbsp;Peterson in respect of the
six-month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Adoption of 2006 Incentive Compensation Plan</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;24, 2006, the Board of Directors of AirNet, upon the recommendation of the Compensation
Committee, adopted the 2006 Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;2006 Incentive Plan&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The purpose of the 2006 Incentive Plan is to promote the following goals of AirNet for the fiscal
year ending on December&nbsp;31, 2006 (&#147;Fiscal 2006&#148;) by providing incentive compensation to certain
employees of AirNet and its subsidiaries:
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Attaining designated levels of pre-tax income;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Improving cash flow and reducing debt;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Defining and executing plans to offset expected declines in Bank Services revenues;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Reducing the fixed cost structure of AirNet; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Meeting high priority deadlines of AirNet.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan include AirNet&#146;s executive officers &#151; Joel E. Biggerstaff
(Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President), Gary W. Qualmann (Chief Financial
Officer, Treasurer and Secretary), Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. (Senior Vice President, Express
Services), Jeffery B. Harris (Senior Vice President, Bank Services), Wynn D. Peterson (Senior Vice
President, Jetride Services), Ray L. Druseikis (Controller and Principal Accounting Officer), Craig
A. Leach (Vice President, Information Systems) &#151; and certain department managers and department
directors. As of the date of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, there were 47 participants in the
2006 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Payments under the 2006 Incentive Plan will be based upon a combination of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income
for Fiscal 2006, the operating performance of AirNet&#146;s Delivery Services and Passenger Charter
Services business segments, and the achievement of personal goals assigned to each participant. The
Compensation Committee approves personal goals for executive officers and reviews the personal
goals for other participants. The personal goals approved by the Compensation Committee for each
of the executive officers relate to specific business objectives related to general business
operations (e.g., regulatory compliance, expense reductions, etc.) and each business segment (e.g.,
execution of specific contracts with customers and vendors, cost reductions, service improvements,
etc.).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">No incentive compensation will be paid under the 2006 Incentive Plan unless AirNet achieves a
designated threshold level of pre-tax income for Fiscal 2006. Once the designated threshold level
is achieved, the available incentive compensation payments will increase based upon predetermined
pre-tax income levels until a maximum aggregate amount of $1.9&nbsp;million in incentive compensation
payments is reached. After the overall amount of incentive compensation is determined based upon
AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income for Fiscal 2006, incentive compensation will be allocated to individual
participants based upon the following four factors: (i)&nbsp;level of pre-tax income attained by AirNet;
(ii)&nbsp;level of contribution margin attained by Delivery Services as compared to certain
predetermined levels; (iii)&nbsp;levels of contribution margin attained by Passenger Charter Services as
compared to certain predetermined levels; and (iv)&nbsp;attainment of personal goals.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">A participant&#146;s maximum incentive compensation payment ranges from 20% to 100% of the participant&#146;s
base salary, depending upon such participant&#146;s level of responsibility for achieving AirNet&#146;s goals
for Fiscal 2006. Twenty percent of each participant&#146;s incentive compensation payments will be
based upon the participant&#146;s achievement of pre-established personal goals. The remaining 80% of
each participant&#146;s incentive compensation payment will be based upon a combination of the other
three factors discussed above, which will be allocated to each participant based upon such
participant&#146;s overall responsibility for attaining the designated levels of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income
and contribution margins for the Delivery Services and Passenger Charter Services business
segments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the event the incentive compensation payments otherwise available for payment under the 2006
Incentive Plan based upon AirNet&#146;s level of pre-tax income is not paid to certain participants as a
result of those participants&#146; failure to attain their personal goals or AirNet&#146;s failure to attain
the predetermined levels of budgeted contribution margins in Delivery Services or Passenger Charter
Services, such unpaid amounts may be awarded at the discretion of the Compensation Committee to
participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan or to other employees of AirNet not participating in the
2006 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The maximum percentage of annual base salary that each of AirNet&#146;s executive officers may receive
as incentive compensation under the Incentive Plan is as follows: Joel E. Biggerstaff, 100%; Gary
W. Qualmann, Larry M. Glasscock, Jr., Jeffrey B. Harris and Wynn D. Peterson, 75%; Ray L. Druseikis
and Craig A. Leach, 50%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Except for payments to the executive officers, payments under the 2006 Incentive Plan will be paid
in quarterly payments commencing with the second quarter of Fiscal 2006 based upon AirNet&#146;s year to
date financial performance. Payments of incentive compensation to executive officers will be made
in the first quarter of the fiscal year ending December&nbsp;31, 2007 based upon AirNet&#146;s performance
and each executive officer&#146;s performance for Fiscal 2006. In order to receive payment, a
participant must be actively employed by AirNet at the time the payment is made. New employees who
qualify for the 2006 Incentive Plan will be eligible to participate on the first day of the
calendar quarter following their date of hire.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Compensation Committee may amend, modify or terminate the 2006 Incentive Plan at any time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Modifications of Amended Credit Agreement</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As
previously reported in &#147;Item&nbsp;5 &#150; Other
Information&#148;, of AirNet&#146;s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for
the quarterly period ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, on November&nbsp;21, 2005, AirNet and its lenders under
the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement dated as of May&nbsp;28, 2004 (as amended, the &#147;Amended Credit
Agreement&#148;) agreed to modify the terms and conditions of the Amended Credit Agreement (the &#147;Third
Change in Terms Agreement&#148;). The Third Change in Terms Agreement modified the fixed charge
coverage ratio and the leverage ratio financial covenants in such a manner that, on a going-forward
basis, the impairment charge recorded as of September&nbsp;30, 2005, in and of itself, would not cause a
default of these financial covenants in the future. At the same time as the Third Change of Terms
Agreement was entered into, AirNet and its lenders executed a waiver of any defaults or potential
defaults under the Amended Credit Agreement which occurred, or may have occurred, as a result of
AirNet&#146;s failure to comply with the foregoing financial covenants due to the impairment charge.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Third Change in Terms Agreement is filed with this Annual Report on Form 10-K as Exhibit&nbsp;4.21
and the description herein is qualified in its entirety by reference to the full terms and
conditions thereof, which terms and conditions are incorporated herein by reference in their
entirety.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;28, 2006, AirNet and its lenders entered into a &#147;Fourth Change in Terms Agreement&#148;
extending the term of the secured revolving credit facility under the Amended Credit Agreement from
October&nbsp;15, 2006 to October&nbsp;15, 2007. The Fourth Change in Terms Agreement also reduced the amount
of the secured revolving credit facility from $30&nbsp;million to
$25&nbsp;million, reduced the amount of
annual capital expenditures permitted under the terms of the Amended Credit Agreement from $30
million to $20&nbsp;million, and modified the calculation of the borrowing base under the revolving
credit facility.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Fourth Change in Terms Agreement
is filed with this Annual Report on Form 10-K as Exhibit&nbsp;4.22
and the description herein is qualified in its entirety by reference to the full terms and
conditions thereof, which terms and conditions are incorporated herein by reference in their
entirety.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>2006 Annual Meeting of Shareholders</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">To date, AirNet has not set a date for its 2006 Annual Meeting of Shareholders. Accordingly, the
information required by Part&nbsp;III (Items 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14) of Form 10-K has been provided as
part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
</DIV>
<DIV align="left">

</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>PART III</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="118"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ITEM 10 &#151; DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Directors of AirNet</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The name, age, principal occupation for the past five years and selected biographical information
for each of the directors of AirNet are set forth below. All information is provided as of March
21, 2006 and was furnished to AirNet by each director. Each director was elected by AirNet&#146;s
shareholders at the Annual Meeting of Shareholders held on December&nbsp;16, 2005 to serve for a term
expiring at the 2006 Annual Meeting of Shareholders and until his successor is duly elected and
qualified, or until his earlier death, resignation or removal from office.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">55
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff, age 49, has served as AirNet&#146;s Chairman of the Board since August&nbsp;2001, Chief
Executive Officer since April&nbsp;2000 and President since August&nbsp;1999. He also served as AirNet&#146;s
Chief Operating Officer from August&nbsp;1999 to February&nbsp;2004. Prior to joining AirNet, Mr.
Biggerstaff served as President of the Southern Region of Corporate Express Delivery Systems, a
national expedited distribution service, from February&nbsp;1998 through July&nbsp;1999. From September
1996 through February&nbsp;1998, Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff provided transportation consulting services and prior
to September&nbsp;1996, he held various positions, including Regional Vice President and General
Manager, with Ryder System, Inc., a company providing transportation and supply-chain management
solutions.
</DIV>

Investment Partners, LLC is the General Partner of Pacific Coast Investment Fund, L.P., a private
investment fund. From April&nbsp;1999 to October&nbsp;2002, Mr.&nbsp;Chadwick was employed by Relational
Investors, LLC, a registered investment advisor that invests in companies that it believes can be
improved. He served as an analyst for Relational Investors, LLC from 1999 to 2001 and became a
Senior Analyst in 2002.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Hellerman, age 68, owns and has served as Managing Director of Hellerman Associates, a
financial and corporate consulting firm, since the firm&#146;s inception in 1993. Mr.&nbsp;Hellerman
currently serves as a director and chief compliance officer for The Mexico Equity and Income Fund,
Inc.; a director of MVC Capital, Inc.; a director and President of Innovative Clinical Solutions,
Ltd., a company formerly engaged in clinical trials and physician network management which is
currently in liquidation; and a director of FNC Realty Corporation, a successor to Frank&#146;s Nursery
&#038; Crafts, Inc., a company which operated the nation&#146;s largest chain of lawn and garden retail
stores, which has emerged from bankruptcy protection under Chapter&nbsp;11 and is currently operating
the properties it owns. Mr.&nbsp;Hellerman also served as a director of Brantley Capital Corporation
until March&nbsp;2, 2006.
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Lauer, age 63, served as the President and Chief Operating Officer of Bank One, Columbus, NA
from June&nbsp;1997 until his retirement in January&nbsp;2001. His primary responsibility with Bank One was
to lead the commercial lending practice in central Ohio. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Lauer, a Certified
Public Accountant since 1968, was the Managing Partner of the
Columbus, Ohio office of Deloitte &#038; Touche LLP from January&nbsp;1989 until he retired in June&nbsp;1997.
Mr.&nbsp;Lauer is also a director of Wendy&#146;s International, Inc., Huntington Bancshares Incorporated,
R. G. Barry Corporation and Diamond Hill Investment Group, Inc.
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

    <TD align="left" valign="top"><B><I>Director since 2002</I></B></TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Parker, age 58, is the Founder and President of IT Management Group, LLC, a specialty
consulting group that advises and manages information technology organizations for corporations in
Europe and the United States. Mr.&nbsp;Parker served as Executive Vice President of Sapient
Corporation, a business and technology consulting firm, from December&nbsp;1999 until his retirement in
July&nbsp;2002. From December&nbsp;1997 to December&nbsp;1999, Mr.&nbsp;Parker served as Senior Vice President and
Chief Information Officer at United Airlines, Inc. From September&nbsp;1994 to December&nbsp;1997, Mr.
Parker was Senior Vice President &#151; Management Information Systems and Chief Information Officer at
Ryder System, Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Parker is also a director of Sapient Corporation.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Riddle, age 64, has been in the growth management and consulting business since July&nbsp;1999,
most recently as CEO of GrowthCircle, LLC a management consulting firm, since August&nbsp;2001, and as
Vice Chairman of Enterasys Systems, Inc., an enterprise network provider, from August&nbsp;2000 to
April&nbsp;2001. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Riddle served from 1997 to 1999 as President and Chief Operating
Officer of Norrell Services, Inc., an outsourcing information technology and staffing services
company. Prior to joining Norrell, for four years, Mr.&nbsp;Riddle served Ryder System, Inc. in
several capacities, primarily in marketing and sales, including as President of Ryder
International. Mr.&nbsp;Riddle served Xerox Corporation for 26&nbsp;years in a variety of senior management
positions, including Vice President of Marketing and Vice President of Field Operations for the
United States
</DIV>

Mr.&nbsp;Riddle is also a director of Danka Business Systems PLC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">There are no family relationships among any of the directors and current executive officers of
AirNet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">James M. Chadwick and Gerald Hellerman were appointed to the AirNet Board of Directors (the
&#147;Board&#148;) effective July&nbsp;20, 2005, and were recommended by the Nominating and Corporate Governance
Committee of the Board. Messrs.&nbsp;Chadwick and Hellerman were recommended to the Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee by Pacific Coast Investment Partners, LLC and Phillip Goldstein,
respectively, in connection with the efforts of a group of AirNet&#146;s shareholders, including Pacific
Coast Investment Fund, L.P., Mr.&nbsp;Goldstein, Andrew Dakos, Pacific Coast Investment Partners, LLC,
Nadel and Gussman Combined Funds LLC, Opportunity Partners, L.P. and Full Value Partners, L.P. (the
&#147;Shareholders Group&#148;), to call a special meeting of AirNet&#146;s shareholders to replace the Board. In
a Schedule&nbsp;13D amendment filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on July&nbsp;7, 2005, the
Shareholders Group reported that it had discontinued its plan to call a special meeting of AirNet&#146;s
shareholders.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Director Independence</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The common shares of AirNet traded on the New York Stock Exchange (&#147;NYSE&#148;) throughout the fiscal
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 (the &#147;2005 fiscal year&#148;) and until January&nbsp;24, 2006. On January&nbsp;25,
2006, the common shares of AirNet began trading on the American Stock Exchange (&#147;AMEX&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Applicable sections of the AMEX Company Guide (the &#147;AMEX Rules&#148;) require, and applicable sections
of the NYSE Listed Company Manual (the &#147;NYSE Rules&#148;) required, that a majority of the members of
AirNet&#146;s Board be independent directors. The definition of independence for purposes of each of
the AMEX Rules and the NYSE Rules includes a series of objective tests, such as the director is not
an employee of AirNet or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries and has not directly or indirectly engaged in
various types of business dealings with AirNet or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries and the director
does not have an immediate family member who is employed by AirNet or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries
as an executive officer. In addition, as further required by each of the AMEX Rules and the NYSE
Rules, AirNet&#146;s Board has affirmatively determined that each independent director has no material
relationship with AirNet or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries (either directly or indirectly).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As discussed below, AirNet&#146;s Board has affirmatively determined that five of the seven directors
(i)&nbsp;qualified as independent directors under the NYSE Rules during the period the NYSE Rules were
applicable to AirNet (i.e., throughout the 2005 fiscal year and until January&nbsp;24, 2006) and (ii)
qualify as independent directors under the AMEX Rules. In making its determination of director independence under the NYSE Rules, AirNet&#146;s Board
established categorical standards (reflecting the objective tests of the NYSE Rules) to assist it
in making its determination of director independence. For purposes of making the determination of
independence under the NYSE Rules, AirNet&#146;s Board defined an &#147;independent director&#148; as a director
who:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>is not and within the last three years has not been an employee of, and has no immediate
family member who is or has within the last three years been an executive officer of,
AirNet or any of its subsidiaries;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>has not received, and has no immediate family member who has received (other than for
service as a non-executive officer employee), during any 12-month period within the last
three years, more than $100,000 in direct compensation from AirNet or any of its
subsidiaries, other than director and committee fees and pension or other forms of deferred
compensation for prior service (provided such compensation is not contingent in any way on
continued service);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>is not and has no immediate family member who is a current partner of a firm that is
AirNet&#146;s internal or external auditor;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>is not a current employee of a firm that is AirNet&#146;s internal or external auditor;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>has no immediate family member who is a current employee of a firm that is AirNet&#146;s
internal or external auditor and participates in the firm&#146;s audit, assurance or tax
compliance (but not tax planning) practice;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>has not been, and has no immediate family member who has been, within the last three
years (but is no longer) a partner or employee of a firm that is AirNet&#146;s internal or
external auditor and personally worked on AirNet&#146;s audit within that time;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>is not and has not been within the last three years, and has no immediate family member
who is or has been within the last three years, employed as an executive officer of another
company where any of AirNet&#146;s present executive officers at the same time serves or served
on the other company&#146;s compensation committee;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>is not a current employee, and has no immediate family member who is a current executive
officer, of a company that has made payments to, or received payments from, AirNet or any
of its subsidiaries for property or services in an amount which, in any of the last three
fiscal years, exceeds the greater of $1&nbsp;million, or 2% of such other company&#146;s consolidated
gross revenues; and</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>has no other material relationship with AirNet or any of its subsidiaries (either
directly or as a partner, shareholder or officer of an organization that has a relationship
with AirNet or any of its subsidiaries).</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s Board determined that each of James M. Chadwick, Gerald Hellerman, David P. Lauer, Bruce
D. Parker and James E. Riddle was independent under these categorical standards. Joel E.
Biggerstaff and Russell M. Gertmenian did not qualify as independent directors under the foregoing
categorical standards.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In making its determination as to the independence of AirNet&#146;s directors under the AMEX Rules,
AirNet&#146;s Board reviewed, considered and discussed the specific objective tests included in the AMEX
Rules (which are generally more stringent than the specific objective tests included in the NYSE
Rules), in light of:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the relationships (including commercial, industrial, banking, consulting, legal,
accounting, charitable and family relationships) of each director (and the immediate family
members of each director) with AirNet and/or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries (either directly
or as a partner, shareholder, officer or member of any organization that has any such
relationship), in each case during the current fiscal year or any of the past three fiscal
years; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the compensation and other payments each director (and the immediate family members of
each director):</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="6%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>

<TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><FONT style="font-size: 85%">o</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>has received from or made to AirNet and/or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries (either

received compensation or payments from or made payments to AirNet and/or any of AirNet&#146;s
subsidiaries), in each case during the current fiscal year or any of the past three

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s Board has determined that each of James M. Chadwick, Gerald Hellerman, David P. Lauer,

has no relationship, either directly or indirectly, with AirNet or any of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries,

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Joel E. Biggerstaff </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Chairman of the Board since August&nbsp;2001, Chief Executive
Officer since April&nbsp;2000, and President since August&nbsp;1999. He also served as AirNet&#146;s Chief
Operating Officer from August&nbsp;1999 to February&nbsp;2004. He has also served as a director of AirNet
since May&nbsp;2000. Prior to joining AirNet, Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff served as President of the Southern
Region of Corporate Express Delivery Systems, a national expedited distribution service, from
February&nbsp;1998 through July&nbsp;1999. From September&nbsp;1996 through February&nbsp;1998, Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff
provided transportation consulting services and prior to September&nbsp;1996, he held various positions,
including Regional Vice President and General Manager, with Ryder System, Inc., a company providing
transportation and supply-chain management solutions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Gary W. Qualmann </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Secretary since
September&nbsp;2003. From February&nbsp;2002 through August&nbsp;2003, Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann served as Chief Financial
Officer and Treasurer of Metatec, Inc., a manufacturer and distributor of electronic media which
filed a voluntary petition for reorganization under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code
on October&nbsp;17, 2003. Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann provided financial consulting services to Metatec from October
2001 through February&nbsp;2002. From March&nbsp;1996 until June&nbsp;2001, Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann was Chief Financial
Officer, Treasurer and Secretary of MindLeaders.com, Inc., an e-learning company based in Columbus,
Ohio. From May&nbsp;1988 until July&nbsp;1995, Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann served as Executive Vice President and Chief
Financial Officer of Red Roof Inns, Inc., a lodging company based in Hilliard, Ohio.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Senior Vice President, Express Services since
February&nbsp;2003. From February&nbsp;2002 through February&nbsp;2003, Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock served as Senior Vice
President of Evercom Systems, Inc., a national provider of telecom services. From April&nbsp;2001
through February&nbsp;2002, Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock served as Executive Vice President of NextJet Technologies, a
software and technology solutions organization. Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock served as Chief Executive Officer of
Expedited Delivery Systems, Inc., a time-definite trucking concern, from August&nbsp;1999 to September
2000 and as its President and Chief Operating Officer from January&nbsp;1998 through August&nbsp;1999.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Jeffery B. Harris </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Senior Vice President, Bank Services since May&nbsp;2000. Mr.
Harris joined AirNet in June&nbsp;1996 as the relationship manager for Banking Sales and was appointed
Vice President, Sales in the banking division in October&nbsp;1997.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Wynn D. Peterson </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Senior Vice President, Jetride Services since June&nbsp;2005.
From January&nbsp;2005 until June&nbsp;2005, Mr.&nbsp;Peterson served as AirNet&#146;s Vice President, Strategic
Planning and Analysis and prior thereto, he had served since February&nbsp;2000 as Vice President of
Corporate Development. Mr.&nbsp;Peterson joined AirNet in 1997 as Manager of Corporate Development.
Prior to joining AirNet, Mr.&nbsp;Peterson managed equity and fixed income portfolios from 1993 until
1997 at Desert Mutual, a pension and benefits company in Salt Lake City, Utah. From 1988 until
1993, Mr.&nbsp;Peterson held various management positions in Finance, Corporate Development and
Strategic Planning at AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, Inc., in Dallas,
Texas.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Ray L. Druseikis </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Vice President of Finance, Controller and Principal
Accounting Officer since June&nbsp;30, 2005. Mr.&nbsp;Druseikis had served as an independent consultant to
AirNet from June&nbsp;30, 2004 until his election as an officer of AirNet, providing assistance in the
process of documenting and testing AirNet&#146;s internal control over financial reporting for purposes
of satisfying the requirements of Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. Prior to joining
AirNet, Mr.&nbsp;Druseikis had provided contract accounting and financial consulting services to
publicly-traded and privately-owned companies since October&nbsp;2002. In addition, from September&nbsp;2003
to April&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Druseikis served as the Chief Financial Officer of SEA, Ltd., a privately-owned
forensic engineering services company. From February&nbsp;2000 to March&nbsp;2002, Mr.&nbsp;Druseikis served as
Corporate Controller for The Dispatch Printing Company, a privately-owned enterprise with varied
business interests in media, real estate and venture capital. From January&nbsp;1997 to February&nbsp;2000,
Mr.&nbsp;Druseikis served as Controller and Chief Accounting Officer for Crown NorthCorp Inc., a
publicly-traded real estate financial services company.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Craig A. Leach </I></B>has served as AirNet&#146;s Vice President, Information Systems since January&nbsp;2000. Mr.
Leach established AirNet&#146;s Information Systems Department in 1985 and was named Director of
Information Systems in 1996.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">There are no family relationships among any of the directors and current executive officers of
AirNet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Composition of Committees of Board of Directors</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The AirNet Board has three standing committees &#151; the Audit Committee, the Compensation Committee
and the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee. In addition, on April&nbsp;29, 2005, AirNet&#146;s
Board established a Special Committee to oversee the process of reviewing, developing and
evaluating various strategic alternatives to enhance shareholder value. The Special Committee was
dissolved on December&nbsp;16, 2005. On December&nbsp;16, 2005,
AirNet&#146;s Board established a Strategy
Committee to work with management on the ongoing business strategy
and alternatives for AirNet to enhance shareholder value.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Audit Committee</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Audit Committee currently consists of David P. Lauer (Chair), James M. Chadwick, Bruce D.
Parker and James E. Riddle. Each of Messrs.&nbsp;Lauer, Parker and Riddle also served on the Audit
Committee throughout the 2005 fiscal year. Mr.&nbsp;Chadwick was appointed to the Audit Committee
effective July&nbsp;20, 2005. AirNet&#146;s Board has determined that each member of the Audit Committee
qualified as an independent director under the applicable NYSE Rules, and qualifies as an
independent director under the applicable AMEX Rules and under Rule&nbsp;10A-3 under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;). AirNet&#146;s Board has also determined that
David P. Lauer qualifies as an &#147;audit committee financial expert&#148; for purposes of Item 401(h) of
SEC Regulation&nbsp;S-K, by virtue of his experience described above under &#147;Directors of AirNet.&#148; In
addition to the qualification of Mr.&nbsp;Lauer as an &#147;audit committee financial expert,&#148; AirNet&#146;s Board
strongly believes that each member of the Audit Committee is highly qualified to discharge his
duties on behalf of AirNet and its subsidiaries, and satisfied the financial literacy requirements
of the applicable NYSE Rules and satisfies the financial literacy requirements of the applicable
AMEX Rules.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B><I>Compensation Committee</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Compensation Committee is currently comprised of James E. Riddle (Chair), Gerald Hellerman,
David P. Lauer and Bruce D. Parker. Each of Messrs.&nbsp;Riddle, Lauer and Parker also served on the
Compensation Committee throughout the 2005 fiscal year. Mr.&nbsp;Hellerman was appointed to the
Compensation Committee effective July&nbsp;20, 2005. AirNet&#146;s Board has determined that each member of
the Compensation Committee qualified as an independent director under the applicable NYSE Rules,
and qualifies as an independent director under the applicable AMEX Rules, an outside director for
purposes of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Internal Revenue
Code&#148;), and a non-employee director for purposes of Rule&nbsp;16b-3 under the Exchange Act.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee is currently comprised of Bruce D. Parker
(Chair), David P. Lauer and James E. Riddle, each of whom also served on such Committee throughout
the 2005 fiscal year. AirNet&#146;s Board has determined that each member of the Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee qualified as an independent director under the applicable NYSE Rules
and qualifies as an independent director under the applicable AMEX Rules.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Special Committee</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;5, 2005, AirNet&#146;s Board engaged Brown Gibbons Lang &#038; Company to serve as AirNet&#146;s
exclusive financial advisor and investment banker to review, develop and evaluate various
strategic alternatives to enhance shareholder value. The Board established a Special Committee
consisting solely of independent directors to oversee the process of reviewing, developing and
evaluating such strategic alternatives. The Special Committee was comprised of Gerald Hellerman,
David P. Lauer, Bruce D. Parker and James E. Riddle. Each of Messrs.&nbsp;Lauer, Parker and Riddle
served on the Special Committee from its establishment on April&nbsp;29, 2005. Mr.&nbsp;Hellerman was
appointed to the Special Committee on August&nbsp;9, 2005. The
Special Committee was dissolved on
December&nbsp;16, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Strategy Committee</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On
December&nbsp;16, 2005, AirNet&#146;s Board established a Strategy
Committee to work with management on the ongoing business strategy
and alternatives for AirNet to enhance shareholder value. The
Strategy Committee is currently comprised of Bruce D. Parker and James M. Chadwick.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Procedures for Recommending Director Candidates</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The procedures for recommending director candidates for consideration by the Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee of AirNet&#146;s Board are described under the caption entitled &#147;ELECTION
OF DIRECTORS &#150; Nominating Procedures&#148; in AirNet&#146;s definitive Proxy Statement for the Annual Meeting
of Shareholders held on December&nbsp;16, 2005. As of the date of this Annual Report on Form 10-K,
those procedures have not changed.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Section&nbsp;16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Pursuant to Section 16(a) of the Exchange Act, ownership of and transactions in AirNet&#146;s common
shares by executive officers, directors and persons who beneficially own more than 10% of the
common shares for purposes of Section&nbsp;16 of the Exchange Act, are required to be reported to the
SEC. Based solely on a review of copies of the reports furnished to AirNet and written
representations that no other reports were required, AirNet believes that during the 2005 fiscal
year, all filing requirements were complied with, except that each of James M. Chadwick and Gerald
Hellerman, who are directors of AirNet, filed late one report, covering one transaction &#150; the
automatic grant of an option.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Corporate Governance Documents</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s Board has adopted charters for each of the Audit Committee, the Compensation Committee and
the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee as well as Corporate Governance Guidelines.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, the AirNet Board has adopted a Code of Business Conduct and Ethics covering the
directors, officers and employees (team members) of AirNet and its subsidiaries, including AirNet&#146;s
Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President (the principal executive officer),
AirNet&#146;s Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Secretary (the principal financial officer) and
AirNet&#146;s Vice President of Finance, Controller and Principal Accounting Officer (the principal
accounting officer). AirNet intends to disclose the following under the &#147;Corporate Governance&#148;
link on the &#147;Investor Relations&#148; page of its website located at www.airnet.com within the required
four business days following their occurrence: (A)&nbsp;the date and nature of any amendment to a
provision of its Code of Business Conduct and Ethics that (i)&nbsp;applies to AirNet&#146;s principal
executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, or
persons performing similar functions, (ii)&nbsp;relates to any element of the &#147;code of ethics&#148;
definition enumerated in Item 406(b) of SEC Regulation&nbsp;S-K, and (iii)&nbsp;is not a technical,
administrative or other non-substantive amendment; and (B)&nbsp;a description of any waiver (including
the nature of the waiver, the name of the person to whom the waiver was granted and the date of the
waiver), including an implicit waiver, from a provision of the Code of Business Conduct and Ethics
granted to AirNet&#146;s principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting
officer or controller, or persons performing similar functions, that relates to one or more of the
items set forth in Item 406(b) of SEC Regulation&nbsp;S-K. In addition, AirNet will disclose any
waivers of the Code of Business Conduct and Ethics granted to a director or an executive officer of
AirNet in a current report on Form 8-K within four business days following their occurrence.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The text of each of the Audit Committee Charter, the Compensation Committee Charter, the Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee Charter, the Corporate Governance Guidelines and the Code of
Business Conduct and Ethics is posted under the &#147;Corporate Governance&#148; link on the &#147;Investor
Relations&#148; page of AirNet&#146;s website located at www.airnet.com. Interested persons may also obtain
copies of the Audit Committee Charter, the Compensation Committee Charter, the Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee Charter, the Corporate Governance Guidelines and the Code of
Business Conduct and Ethics, without charge, by writing to the Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer
and Secretary of AirNet at AirNet Systems, Inc., 7250 Star Check
Drive, Columbus, Ohio 43217,
Attention: Gary W. Qualmann. In addition, AirNet&#146;s Code of Business Conduct and Ethics was filed
as Exhibit&nbsp;14 to AirNet&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Communications with the Board</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In accordance with AirNet&#146;s Corporate Governance Guidelines, the non-management directors of AirNet
meet (without management present) at regularly scheduled executive sessions at least twice per year
and at such other times as the directors deem necessary or appropriate. James E. Riddle has been
chosen as the lead director and presides at all executive sessions of the non-management directors
of AirNet. In addition, at least once a year, the independent directors of AirNet meet in
executive session. Mr.&nbsp;Riddle also presides at those meetings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s Board believes it is important for shareholders to have a process to send communications
to the Board and its individual members. Accordingly, shareholders who wish to communicate with
AirNet&#146;s Board or a particular director may do so by sending a letter to such individual or
individuals, in care of AirNet, to AirNet&#146;s executive offices at 7250 Star Check Drive, Columbus,
Ohio 43217. The mailing envelope must contain a clear notation indicating that the enclosed
letter is a &#147;Shareholder &#150; Board Communication&#148; or &#147;Shareholder &#150; Director Communication,&#148; as
appropriate. All such letters must identify the author as a shareholder and clearly state whether
the intended recipients are all members of AirNet&#146;s Board or certain specified individual
directors. Copies of all such letters will be circulated to the appropriate director or
directors. In addition, shareholders may contact the directors through the Mysafeworkplace.com
Hotline. The Mysafeworkplace.com Hotline can be reached at 800-461-9330 or via e-mail at
www.mysafeworkplace.com. All shareholder communications through the Mysafeworkplace.com Hotline
are categorized by incident type and are then referred to David P. Lauer, Chair of the Audit
Committee; Gary W. Qualmann, Chief Financial Officer, Secretary and Treasurer of AirNet; and/or
Beth Filipkowski, Director of Human Resources of AirNet, depending on the subject matter. All
communications involving accounting, securities, ethical or regulatory issues are referred to Mr.
Lauer.
</DIV>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="119"></A>
</DIV>

AirNet&#146;s four other most highly compensated executive officers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Grants of Options</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">There were no options granted to Messrs.&nbsp;Biggerstaff, Harris, Qualmann, Glasscock or Peterson
during the 2005 fiscal year. AirNet has never granted stock appreciation rights.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">62

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(1)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Each option was granted under the AirNet Systems, Inc. Amended and Restated 1996 Incentive
Stock Plan, (the &#147;1996 Plan&#148;). Each option vested and became exercisable as to 20% of the
common shares covered thereby on the grant date and vests (or vested) and becomes (or became)
exercisable as to 20% of the common shares on each of the first, second, third and fourth
anniversaries of the grant date. At the discretion of the Compensation Committee, the
options may have stock-for-stock exercise and tax withholding features. If AirNet merges
with another entity and AirNet is not the survivor in the merger, or if all or substantially
all of AirNet&#146;s assets or stock is acquired by another entity, each option which has not
expired, been cancelled or been exercised prior to the effective date of such event, will
immediately vest and become exercisable in full. If the employment of the option holder is
terminated by reason of death or total disability, the vested portion of the option may be
exercised for a period of 12&nbsp;months, subject to its stated term. If the employment of the
option holder is terminated for any other reason, the vested portion of the option may be
exercised for a period of three months, subject to its stated term.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(2)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&#147;Value of Unexercised In-the-Money Options at Fiscal Year-End&#148; is calculated on the basis of
the number of common shares subject to each option, multiplied by the excess of the fair
market value of AirNet&#146;s common shares on December&nbsp;31, 2005 ($3.41), over the exercise price
of the option. None of the options held by the named individuals were in-the-money on
December&nbsp;31, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Executive Officer Perquisites and Certain Other Executive Compensation</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The executive officers of AirNet are entitled to participate in the AirNet Systems, Inc.
Retirement Savings Plan on the same terms as all other employees. In addition, they are eligible
to participate in the employee benefit programs maintained by AirNet, including medical, dental
and disability insurance plans, on the same terms as all other employees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Employment Contracts and Termination of Employment and Change-in-Control Arrangements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Employment
Agreements with Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff and Mr.&nbsp;Harris</I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Each of Joel E. Biggerstaff, Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President, and
Jeffery B. Harris, Senior Vice President, Bank Services, is party to an employment agreement
with AirNet, effective as of March&nbsp;1, 2001. Each employment agreement provided for an initial
employment period ending December&nbsp;31, 2001, which has been and will be automatically renewed
for successive one-year periods unless either party gives notice to the other of non-renewal at
least 90&nbsp;days prior to the end of the relevant employment period. Messrs.&nbsp;Biggerstaff and
Harris were entitled to receive initial annual base salaries of $300,000 and $230,000,
respectively, which may be adjusted upward or downward on an annual basis by the Compensation
Committee based on its review of each individual&#146;s performance. Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff&#146;s annual base
salary for the 2005 fiscal year was $325,000 and will remain at that amount for the 2006 fiscal
year. Mr.&nbsp;Harris&#146; base salary was $230,000 for the 2005 fiscal year and will remain at that
amount for the 2006 fiscal year. Each individual is entitled
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">63
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">to participate in any bonus plan
which AirNet may establish and in the incentive stock plans of AirNet (i.e., the 1996 Plan and
the AirNet Systems, Inc. 2004 Stock Incentive Plan ( the &#147;2004
Plan&#148;)), in each case at levels determined by the Compensation Committee. Each individual is
also entitled to receive all health and life insurance coverages, sick leave and disability
programs, tax-qualified retirement plan contributions, paid holidays and vacations, perquisites
and other fringe benefits provided by AirNet to its actively employed senior executives.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">If the named individual&#146;s employment is terminated by AirNet without &#147;cause&#148; (as defined in his
employment agreement) or by the individual for &#147;good reason&#148; (as defined in his employment
agreement), he will be entitled to have his base salary and fringe benefits (other than under the
1996 Plan and the 2004 Plan) continued at the level then in effect for a period of 24&nbsp;months (in
the case of Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff) or 12&nbsp;months (in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Harris, with group medical insurance
continuing for 18&nbsp;months). These periods are extended to 36&nbsp;months and 18&nbsp;months, respectively, if
the termination occurs on or after a &#147;change in control&#148; (as defined in each employment
agreement). Each individual would also be entitled to receive a single lump sum payment equal to
the pro-rata portion (based on days employed during the fiscal year in which employment
terminated) of any non-discretionary bonus payable based on employment throughout the fiscal year;
become fully vested in all employee benefit programs (other than the Retirement Savings Plan, in
which his interest would vest according to the Retirement Savings Plan&#146;s terms); receive a lump
sum payment equal to his non-vested interest in the Retirement Savings Plan to the extent
forfeited upon termination of employment; and be paid his reasonable, out-of-pocket fees and
expenses in connection with outplacement services, in an amount not to exceed $15,000. &#147;Cause&#148; is
defined in each employment agreement to include: (i)&nbsp;any willful breach of the material terms of
the employment agreement; (ii)&nbsp;any willful breach of a material duty of employment assigned to the
named individual pursuant to the terms of his employment agreement; (iii)&nbsp;material refusal to
perform the duties assigned to the named individual pursuant to his employment agreement; (iv)
theft or embezzlement of a material amount of AirNet&#146;s property; (v)&nbsp;fraud; or (vi)&nbsp;indictment for
criminal activity other than minor misdemeanor traffic offenses. The following events qualify as
&#147;good reason&#148; for each individual to terminate his employment: (a)&nbsp;without the named individual&#146;s
prior written consent, AirNet assigns such individual to duties which are materially inconsistent
with or result in a material diminution of his position, authority, duties or responsibilities as
set forth in the employment agreement, including failing to reappoint or reelect him to any such
position; (b)&nbsp;the named individual&#146;s base salary is reduced for any reason other than in
connection with the termination of his employment, unless such reduction is in connection with
proportionate reductions in the salaries of all other executive officers of AirNet; (c)&nbsp;without
the named individual&#146;s prior written consent, he is assigned to an office of AirNet located
outside the Greater Columbus, Ohio Metropolitan area; (d)&nbsp;AirNet fails to obtain an agreement from
any successor or assign of AirNet to assume and agree to perform the named individual&#146;s employment
agreement; (e)&nbsp;AirNet provides notice that it will not extend the term of the named individual&#146;s
employment period; or (f)&nbsp;AirNet otherwise materially breaches its obligations to make payments to
the named individual under his employment agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Each employment agreement also provides for the continuation of salary and bonus (reduced by
amounts payable under the terms of any disability benefit plan of AirNet), at the rate then in
effect, following a disability until the named individual&#146;s employment is terminated as a result
of the disability; and for the continuation of fringe benefits (other than under the 1996 Plan
and the 2004 Plan) for a period of 24&nbsp;months (in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff) or 12&nbsp;months (in
the case of Mr.&nbsp;Harris, with group medical insurance continuing for 18&nbsp;months) following
termination of his employment due to the disability.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">If a named individual&#146;s employment were terminated by his death, his beneficiary would be entitled
to receive any base salary that is accrued but unpaid and any fringe benefits then provided by
AirNet in accordance with the provisions of the applicable plan or program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Immediately upon the occurrence of a &#147;change in control&#148; of AirNet (as defined in each employment
agreement), the named individual would become fully vested in all employee benefit programs in
which he was then a participant, including all options and other awards under the 1996 Plan or the
2004 Plan, but excluding any tax-qualified retirement or savings plan as to which the named
individual&#146;s interest would vest in accordance with the applicable plan&#146;s terms.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Each employment agreement contains confidentiality and noncompetition provisions which prevent the
named individual from disclosing confidential information about AirNet and from competing with
AirNet during his employment therewith and for an additional two years (in the case of Mr.
Biggerstaff) or one year (in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Harris) thereafter. In addition, during the named
individual&#146;s employment with AirNet and for an additional two years (in the case of Mr.
Biggerstaff) or one year (in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Harris) thereafter, the named individual may not
solicit or hire, directly or indirectly, any employee of AirNet.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Employment Agreements with Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann and Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock</I></B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On May&nbsp;3, 2005, AirNet entered into employment agreements with each of Gary W. Qualmann and Larry
M. Glasscock, Jr. These employment agreements had been recommended to AirNet&#146;s Board by an
independent third-party compensation consultant and the Board&#146;s Compensation Committee. Under
their respective employment agreements, Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann is to be employed as Chief Financial Officer
of AirNet and Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock is to be employed as Senior Vice President, Express Services. Each
employment agreement provides for an initial employment period ending December&nbsp;31, 2006, which
will be automatically renewed for successive one-year periods unless either party gives notice to
the other of non-renewal at least 90&nbsp;days prior to the end of the relevant employment period.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">64
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Each of Messrs.&nbsp;Qualmann and Glasscock is entitled to receive an initial annual base salary of
$215,000, which may be adjusted upward or downward on an annual basis by the Compensation
Committee based on its review of each individual&#146;s performance. Each individual is entitled to
participate in any bonus plan which AirNet may establish, at the level determined by the
Compensation Committee. Each individual is also entitled to receive all health and life insurance
coverages, sick leave and disability programs, tax-qualified retirement plan contributions, paid
holidays and vacations, perquisites and other fringe benefits of employment provided by AirNet to
its actively employed senior executive officers. Each individual is also entitled to participate
in the 1996 Plan and the 2004 Plan, in each case at levels determined by the Compensation
Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">If a named individual&#146;s employment were terminated by AirNet without &#147;cause&#148; or by the individual
for &#147;good reason,&#148; he would be entitled to receive any base salary accrued but unpaid and any
fringe benefits then provided by AirNet in accordance with the provisions of the applicable plan
or program. Additionally, the named individual&#146;s medical and health care benefits would be
continued for a period of 12&nbsp;months and his base salary continued at the level then in effect for
a period of 12&nbsp;months provided that the level of base salary continued would in any event be at
least $215,000. In addition, the named individual would become fully vested in all employee
benefit programs (other than with respect to any restricted stock issued under the 2004 Plan and
any tax-qualified retirement or savings plan as to which his interest would vest in accordance
with the terms of the applicable plan). He would also be entitled to receive a single lump sum
payment equal to the pro-rata portion (based on days employed during the fiscal year in which
employment terminated) of any non-discretionary bonus payable based on employment throughout the
fiscal year; receive a lump sum payment equal to his non-vested interest under any tax-qualified
retirement or savings plan maintained by AirNet to the extent forfeited upon termination of
employment; and be paid his reasonable, out-of-pocket fees and expenses in connection with
outplacement services, in an amount not to exceed $15,000. &#147;Cause&#148; is defined in each employment
agreement to include: (i)&nbsp;any willful breach of the material terms of the named individual&#146;s
employment agreement; (ii)&nbsp;any willful breach of a material duty of employment assigned pursuant
to the terms of the named individual&#146;s employment agreement other than a breach related to an
assignment that would be a basis for termination of his employment by such individual for &#147;good
reason&#148;; (iii)&nbsp;material refusal to perform the duties assigned to him pursuant to the terms of the
named individual&#146;s employment agreement other than a refusal related to an assignment that would
be a basis for termination of his employment by such individual for &#147;good reason&#148;; (iv)&nbsp;theft or
embezzlement of a material amount of AirNet&#146;s property; (v)&nbsp;fraud; or (vi)&nbsp;indictment for criminal
activity other than minor misdemeanor traffic offenses. The following events qualify as &#147;good
reason&#148; for a named individual to terminate his employment: (a)&nbsp;in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann,
without his prior written consent, AirNet assigns him to duties which are materially inconsistent
with or result in a material diminution of his position, authority, duties or responsibilities as
Chief Financial Officer, including failing to reappoint or reelect him to that position; (b)&nbsp;in
the case of Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock, without his prior written consent, AirNet assigns him to duties which
are materially inconsistent with his professional training and experience or to a position that is
not substantially comparable to his position as Senior Vice President, Express Services; (c)&nbsp;the
named individual&#146;s base salary is reduced for any reason other than in connection with termination
of his employment; (d)&nbsp;in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Qualmann, without his prior written consent, he is
assigned to an office of AirNet located outside the Greater Columbus, Ohio Metropolitan area; (e)
in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Glasscock, without his prior written consent, he is assigned to an office of
AirNet located outside the Dallas-Fort Worth Metropolitan area; (f)&nbsp;AirNet fails to obtain an
agreement from any successor or assign of AirNet to assume and agree to perform the named
individual&#146;s employment agreement; or (g)&nbsp;AirNet otherwise materially breaches its obligations to
made payments to the named individual under his employment agreement. A decision of AirNet not to
renew the named individual&#146;s employment agreement would not be considered &#147;good reason&#148; under the
employment agreement entitling such individual to terminate his employment and receive the
severance benefits discussed above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">If a named individual&#146;s employment were terminated by AirNet for cause or by such individual
without good reason, AirNet would pay him any accrued but unpaid base salary and provide any other
rights or benefits, if any, to be provided under the applicable terms of AirNet&#146;s compensation
plans and programs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Each employment agreement provides for the continuation of the named individual&#146;s base salary and
bonus (reduced by amounts payable under the terms of any disability benefit plan of AirNet), at
the rate then in effect, following a disability until such individual&#146;s employment is terminated
as a result of the disability. Upon termination of his employment because of disability, the
named individual would be entitled to receive any base salary accrued but unpaid and any fringe
benefits then provided by AirNet in accordance with the provisions of the applicable plan or
program; and his medical and health care benefits would be continued for a period of 12&nbsp;months.
In addition, any disability plan in effect as of his date of termination would be continued.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">If a named individual&#146;s employment were terminated by his death, his beneficiary would be entitled
to receive any base salary accrued but unpaid and any fringe benefits then provided by AirNet in
accordance with the provisions of the applicable plan or program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Amounts payable upon termination of a named individual&#146;s employment would be deferred to the
extent, if any, necessary to avoid the imposition of excise taxes and other penalties pursuant to
Section&nbsp;409A of the Internal Revenue Code but not by more than six months plus one day from the
termination date.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">65
</DIV>
